title: Bank of England's Vlieghe sees downside risks to inflation
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Oct 13, 2015, 10:59 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 31 mins Bank of England's Vlieghe sees downside risks to inflation Reuters â€“ 6 minutes ago Print 
LONDON (Reuters) - Newly appointed Bank of England policymaker Gertjan Vlieghe sounded unlikely to support raising interest rates any time soon as he warned of the risks to Britain from the global economic slowdown. 
In his first public comments since joining the central bank's rate-setting committee in September, Vlieghe said on Tuesday there was a greater chance that inflation in Britain would come in below target rather than above it. 
He also highlighted the risks to the country's economy from a global slowdown. 
"There are risks to either side, but given the current low levels of inflation the risks are probably skewed to the downside," Vlieghe told lawmakers in Britain's parliament. 
Earlier on Tuesday, official data showed consumer price inflation in Britain dipped back below zero in September. 
Sterling, which weakened against major currencies following the inflation figures, added to its losses as Vlieghe spoke. 
Investors have priced in a first increase rate increase by the BoE only in late 2016 although many economists expect it will come earlier next year. 
Only one of the BoE's nine rate setters -- Ian McCafferty -- has voted to raise rates in recent months. 
Vlieghe said "one major risk is that global growth continues to disappoint," sounding more worried about the risk of an impact on Britain from the world economy than most other policymakers at the BoE recently. 
"We absolutely have to take into account that we are operating in a global environment, which is adverse, so to speak, in that there are headwinds to growth," he said. 
"It is one of the things that will prevent the UK economy from accelerating meaningfully" from its current pace of growth, he said. 
(Reporting by Ana Nicolaci da Costa and David Milliken; writing by William Schomberg; editing by Andy Bruce)
